document_title: JPMorgan Economic Outlook 2026: Soft landing scenario with gradual normalization
document_content: JPMorgan Economics released its 2026 outlook, forecasting a soft landing with gradual policy normalization. US GDP growth is projected at 2.2% for 2026, slightly above trend, supported by resilient consumer spending and business investment recovery. The unemployment rate is expected to edge up to 4.3% from current 3.7%, representing healthy labor market normalization rather than deterioration. Inflation is forecast to continue its disinflationary path, with headline CPI averaging 2.4% and core PCE reaching 2.3% by year-end 2026, approaching but not quite reaching the Fed's 2% target. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut rates by 100 bps cumulatively through 2026, bringing the fed funds rate to 4.25-4.50% by December 2026. The easing cycle will be gradual and data-dependent, with cuts likely back-end loaded as the Fed confirms inflation sustainably declining. On the fiscal side, deficit concerns persist with federal deficit projected at 6.5% of GDP, requiring eventual consolidation but unlikely to occur in an election year. Corporate earnings are forecast to grow 8-10% in 2026, supported by revenue growth and modest margin expansion as input cost pressures ease. The housing market should stabilize with mortgage rates declining toward 6%, improving affordability modestly. Global growth is projected at 3.1%, with China at 4.5%, Eurozone at 1.3%, and emerging markets at 4.0%. Key risks include: geopolitical escalation (Middle East, China-Taiwan), financial stability concerns from high debt levels, policy errors by central banks, and political uncertainty. The base case assumes no major shocks and continued AI-driven productivity gains. Sector implications: banks benefit from higher-for-longer rates but face NIM compression as cuts begin; technology continues strong on AI momentum; consumer discretionary faces headwinds from higher unemployment; and healthcare remains defensive with stable growth.

metadata.author: Michael Feroli, PhD, Chief US Economist

expected_summary: JPMorgan forecasts 2026 US GDP growth of 2.2%, slightly above trend, with unemployment rising to 4.3% as labor market normalizes. Inflation expected to continue declining, with headline CPI at 2.4% and core PCE reaching 2.3% by year-end, approaching Fed's 2% target. Federal Reserve projected to cut rates by 100 bps cumulatively through 2026, bringing fed funds to 4.25-4.50%. Easing cycle will be gradual and data-dependent, back-end loaded. Federal deficit forecast at 6.5% of GDP; consolidation needed but unlikely in election year. Corporate earnings expected to grow 8-10%, supported by revenue growth and margin expansion. Housing market stabilizing with mortgage rates declining toward 6%. Global growth projected at 3.1% (China 4.5%, Eurozone 1.3%). Key risks include geopolitical tensions, financial stability concerns from high debt, central bank policy errors, and political uncertainty.
